III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
D.A. Blodgett’s St. John’s Home Residential Campus is comprised of six residential
homes [Ryan, Clancy, Harmaan, Hunting, Armock, and Cebelak]. Because the Ryan
and Clancy Homes serve a much younger population, their census is reduced to eight in
each home. The rest of the homes are licensed for ten residents. The campus is
situated along a small creek in a clearing in the middle of a wooded area on Knapp
Street in North-East Grand Rapids. The six homes are modern, well maintained, and
very clean. Cebelak and Armock Homes are currently closed during a low census
period for scheduled renovations. There is ample space and equipment, both indoors
and out, for residents to be involved in a variety of activities. The homes are spacious
and afford spaces for residents to not be crowded, even during inclement weather.
B. Program Description
The DAB St. John’s Home Residential Program is an existing residential treatment
program that is being assimilated into the D.A. Blodgett continuum of services. The St.
John’s Home Program serves Michigan children who have been removed form their
parents’ custody as a result of neglect or abuse and are unable to function in a relative’s
home or foster home. Most children who enter the program have failed in numerous
previous placements as a result of psychiatric issues, psychological issues, or post
traumatic stressors. As a result, the program is well staffed, with an additional staff
being scheduled at Ryan and Clancy Homes to provide more in depth care to a younger
population. All direct care staff are employed full time to reduce the amount of staff that
a resident must deal with, while at the same time providing consistency in programming
and care. Because of relatively high pay and full benefits, there is little staff turnover and
staff education and experience far exceeds rule requirements, with most direct care
staff possessing a college degree. Residents attend community schools. Each home
utilizes a full time therapist. Two full time nurses provide primary medical care to
residents. A full continuum of professional assessment and support service staff are on
2

campus or utilized in the community to meet the wide variety of resident needs. They
include a medical doctor and a child psychiatrist who are on campus at least weekly.
Additional assessment and treatment services are utilized from community services. In
addition to individual and group therapy, the program utilizes a large amount of varied
activities, both on and off campus, to motivate residents and to keep residents
occupied. Meals are cooked family style in the homes and the quality and quantity of the
food is described by residents as exceptional. When residents were interviewed, they
described a high level of attention from staff, did not have concerns with any staff,
spoke highly of their therapist, talked of their involvements in on campus and community
activities, and expressed a high level of satisfaction with their residency at St. John’s
home. A review of resident case files found them to be organized, complete, and up to
date.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
None.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend issuance of a provisional license to this child caring institution, private
– effective 1/1/2010.
